instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2901: What is 820-2901? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Hi Team,
I have a 27" iMac - Mid 2010.  I ran the EFI Test on it and I get the following error. 
Voltage (VG0R) -- MXM (test 1) - Error - Sensor is reading below the low limit
Test Failed.

As I don't have the schematics for the iMac logic boards, can anyone point out for me as to where to look for that sensor so that I can fix this logic board.

Thanks

Raj.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Board is called "white angle" Google for diagram.
This voltage sensor is a simple resistor divider from the main 12V bus <RESISTOR>R5360</RESISTOR>/62. What is the sensor actually reading?
Is this the only failing sensor? Continue ASD on error.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: Thanks Duke, I am out of town will post response tomorrow.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Hi Duke, I am not able to find any diagram on google. Is it possible to help me find out where can I find the <RESISTOR>R5360</RESISTOR>/62 so that I can get this iMac fixed.  
Also regarding your question, if that is the only sensor failing - The answer is yes.  
Regarding the sensor actual reading, I am not aware of that.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Ridiculous

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2901</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is available everywhere.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Hi Duke,
Thanks for all your help.  I found out that one of the resistors <RESISTOR>R7116</RESISTOR> was shorted to ground.  After removing that resistor the short is gone.  I had one more question.  The resistor <RESISTOR>R7116</RESISTOR> has a value of 20K with 1%, 1/16W, MF-LF , 402.... This is too technical for me to understand.  But my question here is that I cannot find the exact resistor as per the specifications of <RESISTOR>R7116</RESISTOR> but instead I have some donor boards which says the following value... 20K, 5%, 1/16W, MF-LF, 402..  Is it OK to use a 5% instead of a 1% resistor.  If not, then what is the next alternative to replace this resistor.  Your help shall be highly appreciated.  Thanks  Raj.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message:
Hopeless, what does <RESISTOR>R7116</RESISTOR> have to do with voltage sensing?! 

Also it says 20 on the diagram as in 20 FUCKING OHM Raj! Yeah that will beep on diode mode DUH!

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: Duke, i have never done this in my life.  I never studied what is Ohms law.  Yes I understand that my answers are weird, but then how do i learn.  Whenever i ask questions, I am kicked away and treated like, don't ever ask your questions again, on this forum.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: I'm sorry. I did my masters on Ohm's law so I studied it for 7 years. I can understand that after only a year doing repairs you don't fully understand how to measure a 20 Ohm resistor.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: Duke, i can say one thing.  If I am explained once how it works, I don't forget, but my basics need to be cleared.  Before going for Jessa or Louis class last year I never did this.  I only used to change screens and parts replacement, which I had made it clear on Rossmann's website where in they ask the background before coming for the course.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: I apologize if I have been rude in any way.  My emotions sometimes run high due to lack of success and ending up to a failure.

threads.title: iMac - 27" - Mid 2010
threads.message: Pages 9-21 in the sheet I gave you go over ohm's law, resistors, how resistors are measured and how they usually fail with graphics. Read it!
